newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: SOCCER-MATCH-FIXING PROBE CLOSE TO CONCLUSION.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-MATCH-FIXING PROBE CLOSE TO CONCLUSION.

text.p: Investigations into bribery and match-fixing allegations in Portugal and Belgium could soon be complete, UEFA secretary general Gerhard Aigner said on Friday.
A special UEFA committee has been poring over reports and conducting interviews for the last six weeks.
The investigating committee might be prepared to submit a report to the executive committee at its next meeting on April 18 and announce its findings soon afterwards.

"I know the group has been working very hard, talking and seeing people," said Aigner. "I can't tell you anymore because I am not involved but I can say we are interested in getting to a conclusion quickly."
UEFA media director Frits Alstrom confirmed the inquiry was close to wrapping up, "perhaps as early as Easter".
The focus of the investigations in Belgium is Anderlecht's 1984 UEFA Cup semifinal against Nottingham Forest.
A Belgian has been charged with blackmail after he claimed the club had arranged for him to bribe the referee and subsequently paid him to keep quiet about it.
Anderlecht lost the first leg 2-0 but won the home second leg 3-0.
The Belgian has since claimed the club asked him to bribe another referee in a match earlier in the same UEFA Cup campaign.
Belgian media reported this week that an Anderlecht official gave evidence to the UEFA inquiry.
The head of Portugal's referees association resigned in November amid a series of match-fixing allegations that rocked the country's soccer officials.
One club chairman and a referee were jailed on bribery charges and Portuguse justice minister Joise Vera Jardim has said there as many as 10 soccer corruption cases pending.
